item.title: DNS over TLS with Unbound
item.description: Recently, Firefox announced it’s roll-out of DNS over HTTPS (DoH). That made me think, "Encrypting DNS…​ Why don’t I do that for my home network?" Well, I’ve now had the opportunity to configure my Unbound DNS resolver to encrypt it’s DNS requests. Unbound has support built-in for DoH’s sibling protocol, DNS over TLS (DoT). Instead of encrypting DNS traffic and masking it as standard HTTPS traffic, it uses the dedicated port 853.

item.title: DNSSEC with Unbound
item.description: Ever want to enable DNSSEC on your Unbound OpenBSD 6.6 server? Me too! Using this article as a guide, I document the process. Unbound ConfigurationUse the ftp command to download the Root Hints. ftp -o /var/unbound/etc/root.hints https://www.internic.net/domain/named.root Download the trust anchor file with the unbound-anchor utility. unbound-anchor Configure unbound.conf. Add the location of the root.hints file and uncomment the lines with the keys auto-trust-anchor-file and val-log-level. /var/unbound/etc/unbound.conf # Uncomment to enable DNSSEC validation.

item.title: Unbound Adblock
item.description: Ever want to get rid of all those annoying internet ads? Me too. I’d been planning on using something like Pi-hole, but recently stumbled upon unbound-adblock, which is perfect for my OpenBSD home router. The setup is very well-documented there, but I provide my own, slightly-modified setup instructions here. Most notably, the cron-job runs at 6:30 AM, not midnight, and I refined the PF rule which redirects DNS requests to Google’s DNS servers.
